word.definition: Adjustment of an organisms internal environment to allow it to maintain a stable equilibrium.
As a mechanism for maintaining homeostasis it is where the action of effectors counteract changes in order to maintain a stable state.
The ability of an organism to keep its body temperature within certain boundaries.
The maintenance of constant osmotic pressure through variations in water/salt concentration.
Containing nitrogen.
Water soluable and nitrogenous product produced as a result of protein metabolism (mammals).
Filtration under high hydrostatic pressure which retains large molecules.

The process by which substances that are required by the body (e.g. glucose) that have previously been removed from the blood (via ultrafilration) are reabsorbed. It occurs in the proximal convolouted tubule.
Abbreviation for Antidiuretic hormone. ADH is secreted by the posterior pituitary gland and changes the permiability of the collecting duct wall.
A gland which is located at the base of the brain and is the 'master gland' of the endocrine system.
Water created by a living organism through metabolism.
The sac which surrounds the glomerulus at the start of the nephron. It is where ultrafiltration occurs.
A thin membrane of fibrous protein that sperates an epithelium from unerlying tissue.
Chemical element with atomic number 7 - key component of amino acids, DNA, RNA etc.
Chemical element with atomic number 6 - key component of carbohydrates, lipids, DNA etc. Also used by plants in photosynthesis.
Organisms that digest their food externally before absorbing the products.
A molecule which is made of a number of nucleotides linked together to form a chain. Examples include DNA & RNA.
The decay of a body or other organic matter.
Oxidization of ammonia into nitrate or nitrite.
The reduction of nitrate into nitrogen.
Abbreviation for Adenosine triphosphate. ATP is the 'unviersal energy currency' it provides enerfy for biochemical reactions in a number of organisms.
The energy required for a reaction/procees to commence.
Abbreviation of Adenosine diphosphate. ADP is ATP less a phosphate group. Removing the phosphate group from ATP releases 30 KJ/mol of energy.
The process of adding a inorganic phosphate group to a molecule.
A protein which works as a catalyst for a biochemical reaction.
The substance on which an enzyme acts.
A monosaccharide sugar. It has several forms, alpha & beta..
A rod-shaped bacterium.
A spherical bacterium.
A bacterium with a rigid spiral structure oft found in stagnant water.

Not retaining the violet stain used in Gram's method which shows that the bacterium has very little peptidoglycan in its cell wall; though the bacteria will have an outer membrane of polyscaccharides and proteins.

Retaining the violet stain used in Gram's method which shows the bacteria has a cell wall primarily made of peptidoglycan but lacking the outer membrane of gram negative bacteria. (also often less toxic)
Peptidoglycan, also known as murein, is a polymer consisting of sugars and amino acids that forms a mesh-like cell wall.
An enzyme that catalyzes the destruction of the cell walls of gram positive bacteria (by removing a the peptidoglycan and causing lysis) that is found in tears.
